body:
Also bumps:
- `ecdsa` v0.17.0-rc.0
- `elliptic-curve` v0.14.0-rc.2
- `signature` v3.0.0-rc.0

Updates to the changes introduced in https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1866.

Requires https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1866.

This removes the unnecessary implementations of `CofactorGroup`.

title: Add `BatchInvert` tests
body:
Shows that https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1864 is working correctly.

Updates `elliptic-curve` to include https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1864.

title: Update `digest` with newtype changes
body: Updates which correspond to RustCrypto/traits#1799

title: Update to `ExpandMsg` changes
body:
Updates to the changes introduced in https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1862.

Requires https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1862.

title: Bump `elliptic-curve` pin
body: Ensure we're compatible with the latest upstream changes to the `elliptic-curve` crate

title: primefield: add `scalar_impls!` and `scalar_from_impls!`
body:
- Adds a `scalar_from_impls!` macro for writing all of the `From` impls needed for a proper integration with the `elliptic-curve` crate
- Adds a `scalar_impls!` macro which calls `scalar_from_impls!` and `scalar_mul_impls!`

Together these help eliminate quite a bit of scalar-specific boilerplate

title: primeorder: rename `test_projective_arithmetic!` macro
body:
It was previously the more verbose `impl_projective_arithmetic_tests!`.

This follows the convention in the `primefield` crate.

title: primeorder: add `scalar_mul_impls!` macro
body:
Adds a macro which writes a series of `Mul` impls for `Scalar` types for both `AffinePoint` and `ProjectivePoint` as operands (and various combinations of references thereof).

See also: RustCrypto/traits#1854

title: Update `VoprfParameters`
body:
This PR updates `VoprfParameters` to the new definition.

Companion PR to https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1814.

title: Implement `TryFrom<Scalar/Projective/AffinePoint>` for `NonIdentity/ZeroScalar`
body: This implement `TryFrom<Scalar> for NonZeroScalar`, `TryFrom<ProjectivePoint> for NonIdentity<ProjectivePoint>` and `TryFrom<AffinePoint> for NonIdentity<AffinePoint>` in the same spirit as #1188 and #1190.

title: Implement `From<NonIdentity>` for `Projective/AffinePoint`
body: This is the equivalent of #1188 for `ProjectivePoint` and `AffinePoint`.

title: Fix warnings on Rust 1.87
body:
There were several new warnings of this nature:

```console
warning: `#[must_use]` has no effect when applied to a provided trait method

        |
    239 |     #[must_use]
        |     ^^^^^^^^^^^
```

title: Implement `From<NonZeroScalar>` for `Scalar`
body:
This implements `From<NonZeroScalar>` for `Scalar`. Unfortunately this can't be implemented on `NonZeroScalar` directly because `elliptic_curve::Scalar` is just a type alias.

Companion PR: https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1847.

title: chore(deps): bump `crypto-bigint` to `0.7.0-pre.3`

depends:

title: p256: inline inner functions of Barrett reduction
body:
This results in a 15%-20% speedup:

    scalar operations/invert
                            time:   [16.393 µs 16.500 µs 16.600 µs]
                            change: [-15.781% -15.313% -14.861%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                            Performance has improved.

title: Revert signature 3 changes
body:
Depends:
 - https://github.com/RustCrypto/signatures/pull/955

title: p256: use `primefield` macros
body:
Write most of the `FieldElement` implementation in `p256` using the same macros we're applying to other crates.

This somewhat mysteriously seems to cause the following performance regression on a macOS/M2 target:

    point operations/point-scalar mul
                        time:   [155.25 µs 155.60 µs 156.13 µs]
                        change: [+2.3080% +2.7473% +3.4111%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                        Performance has regressed.

Drilling down on the issue, it seems related to the `#[inline]` directives on the core arithmetic trait impls:

https://github.com/RustCrypto/elliptic-curves/blob/f259ec4/primefield/src/lib.rs#L511-L529

It would be good to confirm this is a real issue, possibly through detailed codegen examination, though the total size of involved code is relatively large.

However, the change is small enough to be within a range that is difficult to benchmark, and it's not yet clear how other changes (e.g. switching to a `crypto-bigint` backend) will impact performance.

So this commit accepts this performance regression for now with a note to follow up on potentially switching inlining off on the `core::ops` impls to see if that addresses the issue if other code changes don't make this irrelevant.

title: p256: begin using `primefield`
body:
This represents an initial attempt to convert some of the functionality of `FieldElement` to using macros from the `primefield` crate.

Changes have been made carefully and minimally along with benchmarking to ensure this does not impact performance (unlike the last attempt to do this, see #885)

Trying to use the full `field_element_type!` did appear to result in a benchmark regression, so this instead extracts a
`field_element_type_core!` macro (again) and begins to use it in `p256`, ensuring that there are no benchmark regressions.

title: primefield: move more `From` impls into `field_element_type!`
body: More boilerplate in the macro is less copy/paste

title: primeorder: remove unnecessary `must_use`
body:
warning: `#[must_use]` has no effect when applied to a provided trait
    method
       --> primeorder/src/projective.rs:294:5
           |
       294 |     #[must_use]
           |     ^^^^^^^^^^^

title: primefield: fix modulus bit size calculation
body:
Calculates the bit size of the modulus based on the byte length of `FieldBytes` (as opposed to the size of a `Uint`, which may be larger than the bit length of the modulus depending on e.g. platform word size)

This makes it possible to use the full `fiat_field_arithmetic!` macro which implements inversions for `p224`, where the bit size was previously being miscomputed on 64-bit platforms.

Since it's no longer needed, this merges the
`fiat_field_arithmetic_core!` macro back into `fiat_field_arithmetic!`.

title: primeorder: remove `field` module
body:
The functionality has been fully migrated to the `primefield` crate, which supports the latest version of `fiat-crypto`, and includes other ergonomic improvements.

Having a `field` module in `primeorder` never actually made sense anyway, it was just a convenient place to put such macros at the time.

title: primefield: add `test_primefield!` macro
body: Adds a macro which writes all of the currently provided macro-based tests for types which impl `PrimeField`.

title: sm2: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body: Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `sm2` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

title: p224: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body: Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `p224` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

title: p192: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body: Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `p192` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

title: sm2: add comprehensive DSA tests
body:
# Description

Add comprehensive test suite for SM2 DSA implementation.

## Changes

Added new test file `dsa_extended.rs` with the following test cases:

- Test vectors for different message lengths (empty, 1 byte, 32 bytes, 1KB)
- Signature tampering detection tests
- Special message cases (all zeros, all ones, control characters)
- Property-based tests for signature consistency

## Testing

All tests pass successfully. The new tests provide better coverage for:
- Edge cases
- Security properties
- Signature consistency
- Error handling

## Related Issues

N/A

## Checklist

- [x] Tests added
- [x] All tests passing
- [x] No unsafe code
- [x] Documentation comments in English

title: bp256+bp384: `arithmetic` feature
body:
Promotes the previous `wip-arithmetic-do-not-use` feature to a proper `arithmetic` feature.

The previous bugs were in the field implementation. The `bp*` crates now use the `primefield` crate to write their field implementations with macros as opposed to the previous copy/pasted code.

title: bp384: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body: Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `bp384` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

title: bp256: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body: Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `bp256` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

title: Bump `elliptic-curve` crate dependency
body: Follow-up to https://github.com/RustCrypto/traits/pull/1813.

title: primefield: `field_element_type!` now impls `Invert`
body: The trait is sourced from `crypto-bigint`

title: Bump `elliptic-curve` crate dependency
body: This pulls in a new release of `crypto-bigint` as well as bumping `signature` to v3 prereleases

title: primefield: decouple from `elliptic-curve`
body:
This commit removes the last pieces coupling `primefield` and `elliptic-curve`.

Since an elliptic curve is over a finite field, it doesn't make sense for the dependency to go the other way.

title: primefield: have `field_element_type!` impl `Debug`
body: Uses a common `Debug` impl for all field element types

title: primefield: add `shr` methods/trait impls to macro
body: Updates `primefield::field_element_type` to add `shr` methods and trait impls, replacing the copy/pasted definition to one provided by the macro

title: bign256: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body: Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `bign256` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

title: primefield+p384: upgrade to `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4
body:
Updates the field element type generating macros in the `primefield` crate to be compatible with the latest `fiat-crypto` code as postprocessed by `fiat-constify`, and regenerates the `p384` field impls using `fiat-crypto` v0.1.4.

This update leverages `const_mut_refs` to be much closer to the upstream `fiat-crypto` output, while still providing `const fn` support.

This change also starts extracting a `fiat` module within `primeorder` for macros that are specific to `fiat-crypto` output.

With this upgrade in place, upgrading the rest of the curve crates should be comparatively straightforward.

title: p521: use `fiat-constify` with `const_mut_refs` support
body:
With `const_mut_refs` the field implementations can be much closer to the original `fiat-crypto` output, since they write their outputs using mutable references:

https://github.com/RustCrypto/utils/pull/1177

This regenerates the `p521` field implementations and postprocesses them with `fiat-constify`.

It updates all invocations to initialize an output buffer first, then write the output into it.

title: p256: remove unnecessary sub in scalar Barrett reduction
body:
Based on the following Barrett reduction bound analysis:

https://reports.zksecurity.xyz/reports/near-p256/#analysis-of-the-bound-of-barrett-reduction

...the duplicate subtractions are unnecessary, and it was recommended to remove them:

https://reports.zksecurity.xyz/reports/near-p256/#finding-barrett-second-sub

This results in the following performance improvements:

        scalar operations/mul   time:   [38.900 ns 38.957 ns 39.026 ns]
                                change: [-14.379% -14.052% -13.734%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                                Performance has improved.
        scalar operations/invert
                                time:   [20.716 µs 20.758 µs 20.823 µs]
                                change: [-14.817% -14.331% -13.969%] (p = 0.00 < 0.05)
                                Performance has improved.

title: p256: have `FieldElement::to_canonical` return `U256`
body:
The internal representation of `FieldElement` is Montgomery form, so it doesn't make sense for canonicalization to return a `FieldElement`, but rather an integer, i.e. `U256`.

Originally suggested in: https://reports.zksecurity.xyz/reports/near-p256/#finding-mix-type

title: p256: use `U256` for `MODULUS` of `FieldElement`
body:
Previously `FieldElement` was used, however `MODULUS` itself is not a valid field element.

Originally suggested here: https://reports.zksecurity.xyz/reports/near-p256/#finding-mix-type

title: k256: have `serde` feature activate `pkcs8`
body: Closes #1098

title: chore: fix cargo clippy warning
body:
Running cargo clippy reports the following error.

```shell
warning: manually reimplementing `div_ceil`
   --> sm2/src/pke/decrypting.rs:163:18
    |
163 |     let c1_len = (q.bits() + 7) / 8 * 2 + 1;
    |                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ help: consider using `.div_ceil()`: `q.bits().div_ceil(8)`
    |
    = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#manual_div_ceil
    = note: `#[warn(clippy::manual_div_ceil)]` on by default

warning: manually reimplementing `div_ceil`
   --> sm2/src/pke/encrypting.rs:155:26
    |
155 |     const N_BYTES: u32 = (Sm2::ORDER.bits() + 7) / 8;
    |                          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ help: consider using `.div_ceil()`: `Sm2::ORDER.bits().div_ceil(8)`
    |
    = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#manual_div_ceil

```

This commit resolves the issue.

title: k256: use `std::sync::LazyLock` instead of `once_cell`
body:
When building with the `precomputed-tables` and `std` features, uses the built-in implementation of `LazyLock` in lieu of `once_cell::sync::Lazy` thus avoiding the extra crate dependency.

The `critical-section` feature is retained and uses `once_cell::sync::Lazy`. Only enabling `critical-section` will pull in the 3rd party `once_cell` crate dependency.

When `precomputed-tables`, `critical-section`, and `std` are all enabled, uses `once_cell/critical-section` and enables `once_cell/std`, which should use a `std::sync::Mutex` for synchronization.

title: primeorder: use `PrimeField::NUM_BITS` to bound the scalar size during point-scalar multiplication
body: This probably won't affect actual curves much, but it is useful for test curves which have a small order, but the representation size still has to be large. See also https://github.com/RustCrypto/formats/pull/1649

title: p384: remove default `ecdh` feature
body:
This default feature is inconsistent with all of the other curve implementations in this repo, which don't enable the `ecdh` feature by default.

We could go either way, enabling it in all the other curves, or just disabling it here. This PR opts to do the latter, as it's simpler.

Closes #1047

title: ecdsa: add more secp256k1 wycheproof cases

```
wycheproof2blb ~/projects/wycheproof secp256k1-p1316 256 ./wycheproof-p1316.blb ./desc-p1316.txt
```

body:
Bumps [num-bigint](https://github.com/rust-num/num-bigint) from 0.4.4 to 0.4.6.
Changelog

Sourced from num-bigint's changelog.

Release 0.4.6 (2024-06-27)

  • Fixed compilation on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnux32.

Contributors: @​cuviper, @​ralphtandetzky, @​yhx-12243

Release 0.4.5 (2024-05-06)

  • Upgrade to 2021 edition, MSRV 1.60
  • Add const ZERO and implement num_traits::ConstZero
  • Add modinv methods for the modular inverse
  • Optimize multiplication with imbalanced operands
  • Optimize scalar division on x86 and x86-64

Contributors: @​cuviper, @​joelonsql, @​waywardmonkeys

title: Prevent panic when creating a Schnorr from slice
body:
If you pass a byte slice shorter than 32 bytes to Schnorr's Signature::try_from, it panics.

There is a unit test as first commit to test behaviour before and after the fix.

An easy fix would have been to check in `try_from` if the slice was shorted than `Self::BYTES / 2` but this patch makes it more similar to `bign256` and `sm2`.

title: cargo: point `repository` metadata to clonable URLs
body: This tweaks the `repository` fields in Cargo metadata in order to use the correct (i.e. git clonable) URL. The existing GitHub webUI URLs for each package have been retained and moved to `homepage` fields.

body: These started surfacing in recent rustc versions
